pred:
Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles and the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, has achieved a remarkable feat by becoming the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. Sears embarked on a 702-mile trek through the Antarctic, pulling a sled filled with supplies for 38 days, braving 150mph winds and temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius. His journey ended on Christmas Day, more than 12 days ahead of schedule.

The Guinness Book of Records is yet to confirm whether Sears' feat will make it into the record books. The journey, which began from Hercules Inlet where sea ice meets land, is considered dangerous due to the presence of crevasses. Sears, who is not roped to a teammate for safety, had to navigate these treacherous areas using skis.

Sears encountered a challenging phase during the final leg of his journey, hitting a wall with just 38km (24 miles) to go on Christmas Eve. However, after refueling with food and music, he managed to push through and complete his journey. On Christmas Day, he reached the South Pole in blue skies, expressing his joy in a blog post.

Sears' expedition was not just a personal achievement but also a charitable endeavor. He raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake.

Sears' accomplishment has been widely recognized and celebrated. Judy Murray, Andy Murray's mother, congratulated him on Twitter. He is expected to take a few weeks to process his experience before returning to normal life, expressing his eagerness for a shower and food.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

pred:
Michael David Elliot, a 40-year-old man convicted of four murders in 1993 and serving five life sentences in the Ionia Correctional Facility in Michigan, escaped from the prison on Sunday and was subsequently captured in Kankakee Township, LaPorte County, Indiana on Monday evening. Elliot allegedly stole four vehicles during his 24-hour run from the law. He was arraigned in Indiana on auto theft charges.

The LaPorte County Sheriff’s Department had been looking for a stolen black 2002 Chevrolet Monte Carlo when they received a report of its theft at 6:16 p.m. ET on Monday. Within minutes of learning of the theft, Deputy Slawek Czupryna spotted the stolen vehicle and attempted a traffic stop, but the driver fled, leading deputies on a short chase. Stop Sticks were deployed just before 6:30 p.m., and the stolen vehicle lost control and slid into a snowbank at the T-intersection of N 250 E and E 150 N in Kankakee Township, east of LaPorte.

Elliot was pulled from the car by Deputies Czupryna and Wright, handcuffed, and taken into custody without incident. He was described as polite, quiet, and emotionless during the arrest. Elliot was wearing jeans that were too big and "a couple of jackets." It is unclear how he managed to obtain the uniform he was wearing during the escape.

Elliot was arrested without bond on felony car theft and resisting charges. Michigan Governor Rick Snyder thanked the law enforcement agencies that aided in the search and capture of Elliot, and promised a thorough review of the situation that led to the prisoner's escape.

Elliot was convicted of four murders in 1993, and authorities believe he left the Ionia Correctional Facility through the sally port, a secured garage where prisoners are brought into the facility. He then made a three-and-a-half mile trek into Ionia where he carjacked a woman, and the two drove to the Elkhart, Indiana area. The woman escaped at a gas station in Elkhart, and Elliot fled in her Jeep Liberty. The SUV was found in the 4
answers: A convicted killer who escaped from a Michigan prison yesterday and carjacked a woman has been arrested after a car chase in rural LaPorte Country, Indiana, WNDU reports. Michael David Elliot, 40, allegedly stole a woman's red jeep and abandoned it in the small town of Shipshewana, Indiana, this afternoon. A woman spotted the car and called police, who said the vehicle had been seen in the area as early as 5:30am. Knowing Elliot "can go a lot of places in seven hours," police went door-to-door and had schools locked down before releasing students under a heavy police presence. Then a call about a stolen vehicle came in to the LaPorte County Sheriff's Office, and a deputy saw the vehicle and attempted a traffic stop, WOOD-TV reports. But the driver kept going and led authorities on a 5-minute chase. Stop sticks disabled his tires in Kankakee Township; Elliot jumped out and tried to run but was arrested and booked. He was serving five life sentences for the murders of four people when he broke out of the Ionia Correctional Facility yesterday by slipping through a gap in the fencing system.

pred:
On Friday night in Denver, a high-speed pursuit of a stolen tractor towing an attachment occurred through central Denver, starting near City Park and ending in Lower Downtown. The tractor was initially taken from a Denver Water facility at 1600 West 12th Avenue in the Lincoln Park neighborhood. The chase involved multiple Denver Police Department vehicles, including a dozen police cars and a helicopter, as the tractor drove on city streets, sidewalks, and even crossed Park Avenue.

During the pursuit, the tractor was reported to have struck several cars and buildings, causing significant damage. Two police officers were injured in the incident and were taken to a local hospital. By Saturday morning, both officers had been treated and released. The circumstances leading to the chase and the injuries are still under investigation by the Denver Police Department.

Witnesses described the end of the pursuit, with one account stating that the pursuit ended when a police cruiser rammed the tractor head-on, causing the airbags in the police vehicle to deploy. Another witness reported that the tractor driver was apprehended and placed in an ambulance.

The suspect's identity has not been released as the investigation is ongoing. The Denver Police Department has not disclosed any details about the circumstances surrounding the chase, and the investigation is currently being handled by the Denver Police Department.

This incident resulted in significant traffic disruptions in the downtown area, and the Denver Police Department is urging the public to stay informed about the situation through their official channels. For updates on breaking news, residents are encouraged to download the FOX31 and Channel 2 app for iPhone and Android devices.
answers: Imagine looking outside and seeing over a dozen cop cars chasing ... a tractor. That was the scene in Denver last night when a stolen tractor towing an attachment smashed into cars and buildings as it plowed through downtown, the Huffington Post reports. Addie Hooper, 20, was visiting from Texas with family when she looked out a restaurant window onto Market Street and saw a police SUV crash into the tractor: "We were just like, 'Woah, that's crazy!" Hooper tells the Denver Post. Police vehicles rushed the scene and officers jumped out with guns drawn. "We thought they were going to shoot him," she adds. Instead, officers Tased the driver and made sure he was carted off by ambulance. Two officers sustained non-life-threatening injuries, and no reports have emerged of injured pedestrians. "It could've definitely been a lot worse," a witness tells KDVR. No more details have emerged, but police say the slow-speed chase began around City Park and concluded downtown, where officers rammed the tractor to protect pedestrians. Among Twitter videos, this one seems to capture it best. (Read about the easiest suspect chase ever.)

pred:
In the past few days, tensions between Israelis and Palestinians have escalated significantly, following a series of violent incidents. On Wednesday, a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was abducted and killed near his home in Jerusalem. His body was found charred in a forest on the outskirts of the city, and his family believes he was targeted in revenge for the deaths of three Israeli youths who were buried hours earlier. The Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, condemned the murder and promised a thorough investigation. However, the incident sparked clashes between Palestinians and Israeli police, resulting in numerous injuries and property damage.

Meanwhile, Israel has reinforced its forces on its border with Gaza in response to mortar and rocket fire from Palestinian militants. The exchange of fire has led to injuries on both sides, with 10 Palestinians injured in Israeli air strikes and no reports of injuries in the Israeli town of Sderot, where two homes were damaged by the Palestinian attacks.

The funeral of Mohammed Abu Khdeir was delayed due to a post-mortem examination, which is being conducted by Palestinian and Israeli doctors. His father was reportedly held by police for eight hours and allegedly pressured to say his son's killing was not in retaliation for the deaths of the Israeli youths.

The murder of Mohammed Abu Khdeir has been widely condemned, with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas calling for the strongest punishment for the murderers. The family of one of the three Israeli teenagers also issued a statement condemning the latest killing. However, there are fears that the funeral, when it takes place, could lead to further clashes.

The killing of the three Israeli youths, whose bodies were found on Monday, has been blamed on Palestinian Hamas militants, although the group has not taken responsibility. The Israeli government has accused Hamas of using the incident as a pretense to force apart the newly minted unity government supported by both Hamas and the secular Fatah party.

The escalating violence and growing distrust between the two sides have raised concerns about the future of the peace process and the possibility of further escalation.
answers: Mohammed Abu Khudair was heading to morning prayers at 4am yesterday when neighbors saw him forced into a van in east Jerusalem, his father says. They called his cell phone but "my son wasn't answering," his mother adds, per the BBC. An hour later, the Palestinian teen was found dead in an apparent revenge killing, so burned beyond recognition that DNA samples were needed to confirm his identify, father Hussein Abu Khudair tells NBC News, adding, per Time, "The settlers killed my son, they kidnapped him and killed him." More developments: The teen's funeral, originally set for today, has been delayed as authorities perform an autopsy, his father says. Khudair adds he doesn't have faith in the Israeli police "because we're Arab" and says young Jews pulled a 9-year-old boy away from his mother after Mohammed's death. Though he was saved, "he was scratched," Khudair says. "They grabbed him by his neck." Another relative of Mohammed adds "the hatred has increased" instantly in the family's neighborhood. "I've never seen such racism, even in the first and second intifada," he tells the New York Times. "We are entering a very dark time." Meanwhile, police are investigating what could be a third kidnapping after a girl called police from northern Israel. "She said that she was abducted and then the line went dead," an Israeli spokesman tells the Times. "We're searching the area. Helicopters are trying to track. We'll see what's going on there." In response to mortar and rocket attacks from Gaza, "the Israeli Air Force attacked 15 terror sites in Gaza early Thursday," an Israel Defense Forces official notes. "The targets included weapons manufacturing sites as well as training facilities." Some 10 Palestinians were reportedly injured.

pred: In Other Words, a feminist bookstore in Portland, Oregon, has severed ties with the popular TV show Portlandia, which for six seasons used the store as a filming location for its fictional bookstore, Women and Women First. The decision was made in response to a series of incidents where the store was left in disarray, staff was mistreated, neighbors were forced to close, and the store's political and social values were disregarded. The show, which features Carrie Brownstein and Fred Armisen, has been criticized for its trans-antagonistic and trans-misogynist content, lack of diversity, and for promoting gentrification in Portland. The store's management emphasizes that being on Portlandia does not bring in significant financial or political support, as tourists often take photos outside but do not enter the store. The store continues to advocate for social justice and encourages donations and volunteer work.
answers: Portland's In Other Words bookstore is well known to Portlandia fans as the fictional Women and Women First bookstore featured in sketches on the show—but it's safe to say ties have been severed between the bookstore and the show, considering a sign that appears on the bookstore's door reading, "Fuck Portlandia! Transmisogyny – Racism – Gentrification – Queer Antagonism – Devaluation of Feminist Discourse." The Willamette Week tried on Tuesday to get an explanation from the bookstore, and a representative at first offered an interview, but also asked (repeatedly) for the Week to post a link to an online fundraiser the bookstore is running. After the Week declined to guarantee a link would be posted (though one did, in fact, end up getting posted in the ensuing article), the bookstore took back its offer of an interview in no uncertain terms. "After some consideration and research we've decided to officially tell the Willamette Weekly to go fuck themselves," read a message from the rep. "Your paper has absolutely zero journalistic professionalism and you are scummy rape apologists. Thanks for the opportunity tho! Have a great night." Then, Wednesday, a blog post went up on the bookstore's website explaining the "Fuck Portlandia" sign. It was placed on the window, and the store's relationship with the show was formally discontinued, as "a direct response to a particular egregious filming of the show in our space which saw our store left a mess, our staff mistreated, our neighbors forced to close and lose business for a day without warning, and our repeated attempts to obtain accountability or resolution dismissed," the blog post reads. "It was also a direct response to a show which is in every way diametrically opposed to our politics and the vision of society we’re organizing to realize. A show which has had a net negative effect on our neighborhood and the city of Portland as a whole." There's a lot more where that came from, here.

pred:
In a series of investigations, the California State Auditor's Office (State Auditor) has uncovered several instances of improper governmental activities by state employees and agencies. Over a period of several years, these activities resulted in significant financial losses for the state.

One of the most egregious cases involved a DMV data operator who slept for three hours a day at her desk for three years, costing the state over $40,000. Despite complaints from colleagues and evidence of her sleeping on the job, the DMV failed to take disciplinary action. The employee continues to work for the state.

Another case involved two facilities operations employees at California State University, Fresno who engaged in time and attendance abuse by taking extended breaks or leaving campus without accounting for their time, costing the state over $111,000 in salary payments for work not performed.

At Kern Valley State Prison, an employee misused state time by regularly leaving work early, costing the state nearly $9,000. A nursing director at a Southern California prison reassigned a licensed vocational nurse, who was her personal friend, to a position for which she was overqualified, causing the state to waste nearly $30,000 in unnecessary salary payments and overtime.

A staff services analyst at the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation was overpaid nearly $3,000 due to a failure to follow proper procedures. A high-ranking Cal Fire chief built an unauthorized structure on state property using on-duty staff, costing the state resources and time to demolish the structure.

At California State University, Dominguez Hills, a manager directed a staff member to purchase a quick charger for an electric vehicle without ensuring its compatibility with the campus's energy resource plan, resulting in the charger remaining unused for five years.

The California State Auditor's Office conducted investigations into 1,481 cases of alleged improper governmental activities in the past year. The State Auditor's investigative work has led to the remediation of problems and the prevention of retaliation against whistleblowers.

California lawmakers have scheduled an August hearing to examine complaints of long wait times at the DMV. The DMV has faced criticism for its handling of the case of the data operator who slept on the job
answers: An employee responsible for logging changes in address and vehicle ownership at the California DMV slept at least three hours a day at her desk for nearly four years—and still has a job. The woman's 2,200 hours spent napping between February 2014 and December 2017 meant she completed less than half of her expected amount of work and cost the state more than $40,000, according to a worker misconduct report released Tuesday by the state's auditor. Per USA Today, the woman's doctor told the DMV that she was unable to perform her work duties, though a later doctor's note said the opposite. The employee continues to work for the state, per the Sacramento Bee.

In Cairo, Egypt, political tensions escalated on December 5 and continued into December 6 as supporters and opponents of President Mohamed Mursi clashed outside the presidential palace. The Muslim Brotherhood, an Islamist political group, called for a protest at the palace in response to what they described as "oppressive abuses" by opposition parties. The clashes between the two sides resulted in injuries and casualties, with two Islamists reportedly hit by gunfire and a leftist group member having an ear cut off. Vice President Mahmoud Mekky proposed a potential solution to the crisis, suggesting that amendments to the disputed articles in the draft constitution could be agreed upon with the opposition. However, the proposed amendments did not seem to quell the violence, and the clashes continued into the early hours of December 6.

The draft constitution, written by an Islamist-led assembly, has been a contentious issue, with the opposition arguing that it does not properly represent the aspirations of the entire nation. The opposition has also criticized a decree issued by President Mursi on November 22, which granted him wide powers and shielded his decisions from judicial review. The opposition coalition has accused President Mursi of creating a new autocracy and causing the worst crisis since he took office in June.

The United States, concerned about the stability of Egypt, a state with a peace deal with Israel and to which it provides $1.3 billion in military aid annually, called for dialogue to resolve the crisis. The Vice President, Mahmoud Mekky, echoed this call, stating that a written agreement could be reached with the opposition, subject to consensus and respect for opposition demands. However, President Mursi has shown no signs of backing down, expressing confidence that the Islamists can win the upcoming referendum and parliamentary election.

The clashes between the two sides have caused frustration among residents, leading some to set up makeshift roadblocks to check passersby. The violence has also spread to other cities, with offices of the Muslim Brotherhood's political party being torched in Ismailia and Suez. Despite the opposition's calls for Mursi's overthrow, they have yet to generate a mass movement or a grassroots political base to challenge the Brotherhood.

The situation in Egypt poses a "real danger" according to Mek
answers: Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi returned to the presidential palace today after fleeing yesterday when it was thronged by protesters, Reuters reports. Though 200 demonstrators camped out overnight, traffic was back to normal today and riot police had left the area. In yesterday's clashes, 35 protesters and 40 police officers were hurt. And things are looking to heat up again soon: The Muslim Brotherhood has called for a protest at the palace today against the "oppressive abuses" of the opposition, and the opposition in response called for leftist demonstrators to head back to the palace, leading to fears of violent clashes. Opposition protesters want Morsi to retract his expanded powers and stop a Dec. 15 vote on the new constitution hastily drafted by Islamists. Though they called yesterday's protest a "last warning" to the president, Reuters notes that they have little real chance of stopping the vote, which Morsi is confident will approve the constitution.

The Jamaican Bobsled Team is set to make a return to the Winter Olympics after a 12-year absence, competing in the two-man bobsled event at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia. The team, piloted by Winston Watts and Marvin Dixon (JAM-1), has been preparing for the competition and will be making their first run on Sunday, February 16, 11:15 AM EST.

In an effort to support the team and create an exciting atmosphere, a new song titled "The Bobsled Song" has been released. Composed by Sidney Mills and Jon Notar, and produced by Groove Guild, the song is designed to sync perfectly with the rhythms of the bobsled track itself. The lyrics and chorus follow the course of the 1,500-meter (4,921-foot) track with its 17 turns and a vertical drop of 125.5 meters (410 feet).

The song's catchy chorus, "It's bobsled time," reflects the team's progress throughout the race. An eight-bit animated music video for the song is available online, showcasing the team's journey on the Sochi bobsled course.

Jamaica, a tropical island nation, qualified for the two-man bobsled competition for the first time since 2002, without racing in any World Cup events but accumulating enough points in lower-tier races in North America. The team is considered a long shot to win a medal, but their improbable run has captured the attention of fans and the media.

The Jamaican Tourist Board is promoting "The Bobsled Song" as a way for fans to show their support for the team. Fans are encouraged to download the song and press play at the exact moment the Jamaican Bobsled Team begins their run on Sunday.

The team's journey to the Olympics was previously depicted in the film "Cool Runnings." The team's return to the Winter Olympics marks another exciting chapter in the history of Jamaican bobsledding.
answers: Jamaica's incredible bobsledding run to the Winter Olympics now has a theme song to go with it—named, appropriately, "The Bobsled Song," the AP reports. The upbeat tune by Sidney Mills and Jon Notard plays perfectly in sync with the team's 4,921-foot run in Sochi and wraps up with "Last turn, keep your head down/I see the finish line/Jamaica rock the whole town," reports Mashable. (See the 8-bit video here.) Considered a long shot to win a medal, the two-man team of Marvin Dixon and Winston Watts are aiming to recapture the thrill of the 1988 film Cool Runnings and ride the crowd-funding high that paid for country's first bobsledding Olympic appearance since 2002.

pred:
Two former Nazi SS guards, aged 93 and 92, have been indicted by German prosecutors for their roles as accessories to murder while serving at the Stutthof concentration camp during World War II. The camp, located near Gdansk, Poland, was notorious for the deaths of approximately 65,000 prisoners, including Jews, Poles, and Soviet prisoners of war. The guards are accused of being aware of various killing methods, such as gas chambers, shootings, and injections with gasoline and phenol, and of willingly supporting hundreds of killings in their roles as guards.

One of the indicted guards, Johann Rehbogen, has been identified by Holocaust survivor Judy Meisel, who was a prisoner at Stutthof. Meisel, now 88, has been working with German authorities to bring charges against the guards, and she could potentially serve as a co-plaintiff in the case. She has provided crucial details about life in the camp and identified Rehbogen, who was known for taunting prisoners.

The indictments are significant as they represent a new legal approach in Germany, allowing the prosecution of former Nazis who can't be tied to specific killings. The defendants will have an opportunity to challenge the indictments and will likely be evaluated by medical experts for their fitness to stand trial. If deemed healthy enough, the trial could commence next summer.

Meisel, who lost her mother and sister in the camp, views the indictments as a chance to find answers and seek justice for her family. She is prepared to relive her horrific experiences to help the prosecution challenge the defendants' denials of knowledge about the killings. Despite the emotional toll, Meisel welcomes the opportunity to share her story for the important lessons it teaches about tolerance and racism.
answers: Judith Meisel says that when she was a teenager in the Stutthof concentration camp in western Poland, other prisoners told her: "Don't let us die without you mentioning what happened to us." The 88-year-old Minnesota resident has not forgotten: Her testimony helped German authorities indict two former guards from the camp where 65,000 people, including Meisel's mother, died, the Minneapolis Star Tribune reports. She identified one former guard, 94-year-old Johann Rehbogen, as the young SS officer who would taunt female prisoners as they undressed. Prosecutors say the men can't be tied to specific murders, but their work as guards made the killings possible. Meisel—who escaped along with her sister when inmates were sent on a "death march" away from the camp in 1945—says she is willing to relive her horrific experiences to help prosecutors. "This process of seeking answers and finding justice for my mother gives new meaning to my life," she says. The two former guards have been charged as accessories to murder, the AP reports. They deny any knowledge of killings at the camp, where thousands were starved to death or froze. Prosecutors say prisoners were also gassed to death, shot, and killed with lethal injections. Authorities say Meisel and several other Stutthof survivors in the US could be called as witnesses if the former guards are deemed healthy enough to stand trial. (A pendant found at the Sobibor camp helped reunite a family.)

In the realm of politics and entertainment, two significant events have unfolded recently.

Firstly, a woman named Heather Lind, an actress, has accused former President George H.W. Bush of sexual assault during a photo opportunity in 2014. According to Lind's Instagram post, which has since been deleted, Bush made inappropriate physical contact and told a lewd joke while his wife, Barbara Bush, was present. The post has been supported by several of Lind's colleagues, including co-star Kevin McNally and the author of the book on which the show "Turn" is based.

In response to these allegations, Bush issued an apology, stating that his actions were not intended to cause distress and were meant as an attempt at humor. However, Lind has expressed that she does not respect Bush due to the incident.

In a separate development, another actress, Jordana Grolnick, has come forward with similar accusations against Bush. Grolnick claims that Bush inappropriately touched her during a photo opportunity in 2016.

Meanwhile, in a different context, a woman has expressed her perspective on the power held by individuals, comparing it to that of a President. She believes that one can use their power to enact positive change, help people, and serve as a symbol of democracy. She emphasized that the character and integrity of a leader are crucial, as these qualities shape their political decisions.

This summary is a condensed version of several news passages discussing these events. For a more detailed understanding, it is recommended to refer to the original sources.
answers: Actress Heather Lind accused former President George HW Bush of sexual assault in a now-deleted Instagram post Tuesday, saying the former president "touched her from behind" during a photo-op in 2014. The Turn: Washington's Spies star said the inappropriate behavior occurred during a special screening before the AMC historical drama's debut, Deadline reports. "He touched me from behind from his wheelchair with his wife Barbara Bush by his side," Lind wrote. "He told me a dirty joke. And then, all the while being photographed, touched me again. Barbara rolled her eyes as if to say 'not again.'" Lind said a security guard told her she "shouldn't have stood next to him for the photo." Lind said that judging from comments from people around her, Bush had behaved the same way with "countless other women." "My fellow castmates and producers helped me that day and continue to support me," she wrote. Lind said she decided to come forward with her story after seeing a recent photo of the 93-year-old Bush with former President Obama. Bush issued an apology through a spokesman. "President Bush would never—under any circumstance—intentionally cause anyone distress, and he most sincerely apologizes if his attempt at humor offended Ms. Lind," the spokesman said in a statement to the New York Daily News.

answers: Tunisia was not pleased today when a battle between Libya’s warring factions spilled across the border today, after Moammar Gadhafi’s forces attacked a rebel-held frontier crossing. The incursion was brief and limited, and Gadhafi’s forces even apologized locally, Reuters reports. But Tunisia’s foreign ministry still issued a statement expressing “extreme indignation” and demanding “measures to put an immediate stop to these violations.” But Tunisia has proven remarkably welcoming to Libyans who aren’t fighting. Only about 2,500 have had to settle in the relatively small refugee camp at the border. “It’s the first time I’ve seen such an impressive response,” says a spokesman for the UN’s High Commissioner for Refugees.

answers: A tourist boat packed with about 160 passengers capsized Sunday on a reservoir near the Colombian city of Medellin, leaving at least six people dead and 31 missing, officials said. Rescuers including firefighters and air force pilots in helicopters searched for survivors at the Guatape reservoir where El Almirante ferry sank. A flotilla of recreational boats and jet skis rushed to the scene, pulling people from the boat as it went down and avoiding an even deadlier tragedy, the AP reports. Dramatic videos circulating on social media show the party boat rocking back and forth as people crawled down from a fourth-floor roof as it began sinking into the water. "Those on the first and second floors sank immediately," a female survivor told Teleantioquia. "The boat was sinking and all we could do was scream and call for help." Survivors described hearing a loud explosion near the men's bathroom that knocked out power a few minutes after the boat began its cruise around the lake. It's unclear what caused the boat to sink, but survivors said that it appeared to be overloaded and nobody on board was wearing a life vest. After arriving at the scene, Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos said 122 people were either rescued or found their way to shore, but six had died and another 31 were missing, he told reporters.

pred:
The news articles and a documentary highlight the life and philanthropic work of Julius Rosenwald, a Jewish American businessman and philanthropist, who transformed Sears, Roebuck into the country's most significant retailer in the early 20th century. Born to German immigrant parents, Rosenwald's meteoric rise in business was matched by his dedication to philanthropy, particularly in African-American education and culture.

Rosenwald's philanthropy had a profound impact on African-American communities, particularly in the Jim Crow South. He funded the construction of more than 5,300 schools, many of which bore his name, and provided seed money for YMCAs, apartments, and cultural institutions for African Americans. His philanthropy also supported the careers of notable African-American artists like Langston Hughes, Marion Anderson, and Jacob Lawrence.

The documentary "Rosenwald" was screened at the NAACP convention in Philadelphia, where it was revealed that Alex Bethea, a vice principal in New Jersey, attended a Rosenwald school without knowing its namesake. The film celebrates the cooperation between African-Americans and Jews and speaks to the Jewish tradition of tikkun olam, or repairing the world.

The documentary features interviews with civil rights leaders like John Lewis and Julian Bond, who attended Rosenwald schools, and prominent African-American artists and intellectuals. It also delves into Rosenwald's personal life, including his upbringing in Springfield, Illinois, and his business partnership with Richard Sears.


The documentary serves as a testament to Rosenwald's life and work, showcasing his commitment to ensuring that African-American children received a quality education and his belief in the power of cooperation between different communities. The film's release is scheduled for mid-August, with a wider release planned for the fall. The documentary aims to inspire continued philanthropy and social action in the spirit of Rosenwald.
answers: Julius Rosenwald is well known as the 20th-century American businessman who co-founded what we now call Sears. But a new documentary by Aviva Kempner explores Rosenwald's lesser-known role as a Jewish philanthropist who brought education to thousands of African-American children at a time when most had no schools to attend, reports the Root. "It's a wonderful story of cooperation between this philanthropist who did not have to care about black people, but who did, and who expended his considerable wealth in ensuring that they got their fair shake in America," civil rights leader Julian Bond explains in Rosenwald, out next month. It tells of Rosenwald's rise from the son of a peddler to a clothing manufacturing apprentice to CEO of the largest US retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Co., in 1908, reports the Times of Israel. It was around that time he began to see similarities between the treatment of blacks in America and pogroms against European Jews. When his rabbi became an NAACP leader, Rosenwald sponsored meetings. Soon after, he donated $25,000 to Alabama's Tuskegee University, led by Booker T. Washington, whose writings on racial equality and education had piqued his interest. Washington suggested the money go toward building six schools for black children, but Rosenwald contributed just a third of the funds and pushed the black and white communities to raise the rest. He went on to give $62 million to various causes, including the Rosenwald Fund, which created 5,300 schools in the South, attended by prominent African-Americans like Maya Angelou, George Wolfe, and Eugene Robinson. It "was the single-most important funding agency for African-American culture in the 20th century," poet Rita Dove says. More than 80 years after his death, Rosenwald still inspires. "Not all of us can be Julius Rosenwald," says Kempner, but "we can all do something."

The news articles discuss the need for encouraging girls to become leaders in the workforce, particularly in corporate leadership positions, as the 20-year anniversary of the Ms. Foundation's Take Our Daughters to Work Day has passed. The articles suggest that while the initial goal of demystifying the workplace for girls has been achieved, what is now required is a shift in focus towards encouraging girls to aspire to leadership roles.

The articles highlight the underrepresentation of women in leadership positions, particularly in Fortune 500 companies, where women make up only 3.6% of CEOs, 14% of executive officers, and 16% of board directors. The articles argue that companies need to do more to inspire women to lead, rather than blaming the lack of women leaders on an "ambition gap."

The articles propose several strategies to address this issue. First, they suggest introducing girls to female role models, particularly those in high-ranking positions, to give them a tangible example of what they can aspire to become. Second, they suggest explaining the specific responsibilities, rewards, and challenges of leadership roles to make leadership more tangible and accessible to girls. Third, they suggest supporting programs throughout the year that actively identify and groom female talent.

The articles also emphasize the importance of proactive efforts to move women into leadership roles, citing examples such as Princeton University's steering committee that proactively encouraged female students to apply for academic prizes.

Finally, the articles highlight the role of sponsorship in corporate environments, where sponsors spend their political capital on behalf of their protégés, providing opportunities instead of merely advice. The articles argue that formal sponsorship initiatives can help achieve similar results.

In conclusion, the articles call for a shift in focus from Take Our Daughters to Work Day to Take Our Daughters to the C-Suite Day, emphasizing the need for girls to see women in leadership positions and to understand the specific challenges and rewards of such roles. The articles argue that this shift is necessary to address the underrepresentation of women in leadership positions, which is costing companies talent, hurting the country's competitiveness, and undermining ideals of fairness and social equality.
answers: Today is the 20th anniversary of Take Our Daughters to Work Day, and Jennifer Allyn at the Christian Science Monitor says it's time to declare mission accomplished and refocus on a bigger goal. Two decades ago, it was enough to get young girls in the workplace and "demystify" the whole concept of women getting a job. Now it's time to introduce girls to the executive suites, to give them role models of women as decision-makers. Girls still tend not to see themselves getting leadership positions as adults, and that's because they don't get to see enough real-life examples. "Simply showing our daughters what an office looks like is no longer enough," writes Allen. "Real breakthroughs will come when we bring girls inside the halls of power. We need to take our daughters into the C-Suite now so they can lead in the future." Click to read her entire column.

answers: Rasheen Rose died while being restrained at Fineson Developmental Center, a state institution in Queens, on August 6, 2012—a death that was ruled a homicide by the New York medical examiner, and into which the district attorney's investigation is still open. Shaneice Luke, Rose's sister, filed a lawsuit accusing the staff of killing her brother, who "became unresponsive" after at least three staff members allegedly threw him to the ground and put him in a "prone position" for as long as 30 minutes; one 275-pound worker sat on him, while others, including doctors and nurses, stood by, the New York Daily News reports. Rose, who had severe autism and could not communicate verbally, "was basically crushed to death," says Luke's lawyer. But now, New York officials are billing Luke for $11.67 million, the AP reports. The claim against Rose's estate cites his total Medicaid assistance over a period of 10 years, up until the day he died at age 33. Medicaid doesn't typically demand reimbursement, but an attorney who has worked with others who've received similar bills after suing the state says officials have recently begun this "problematic" practice. A spokesperson for the Office for People with Developmental Disabilities, which runs Fineson, says officials are simply following federal Medicaid obligations so that they don't lose their Medicaid funding, but an assemblyman who advocates for people with disabilities calls it "retaliation." Last year, Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced plans to close Fineson in 2017.

The Hatchimal is a plastic egg-shaped toy that hatches into a Furby-like creature after being rubbed, tapped, and warmed for 25-40 minutes. The toy was marketed as the "it" gift of the holiday season, with parents lining up outside stores and bidding up sales on third-party sites. However, many consumers have reported that the toy fails to hatch, leading to frustration and disappointment.

Jodie Hejduk, a mother from Bakersfield, California, filed the lawsuit on behalf of herself and other affected consumers. She purchased a Hatchimal for her daughter as a birthday gift but found that it did not hatch. Hejduk is seeking damages for Spin Master's "deceptive business practices" and alleges that the company misrepresented the toy.

Spin Master has acknowledged receiving complaints and has provided troubleshooting support and replacement products for those whose toys did not work as expected. However, the company denies the allegations in the lawsuit and states that they are "inaccurate and not based on actual facts."

The lawsuit alleges that Spin Master knew the toy's failure rate was high and that the hatching process was a significant draw for the toy. The company's senior vice president recognized that the excitement of not knowing what was inside the egg resonated with children. However, many consumers have reported extreme disappointment and damages due to the toy's failure to hatch.

The lawsuit seeks compensatory, statutory, and punitive damages, as well as a recall of defective Hatchimals. Spin Master has not yet commented on the lawsuit. The case is ongoing, and it is unclear whether more lawsuits will be filed. The Hatchimal craze has left many families disappointed and out of pocket, and the lawsuit seeks to hold Spin Master accountable for its actions.
answers: Hatchimals, the hottest toys of the holiday season, laid an egg with many expectant kids Christmas morning when their furry hatchlings refused to come out of their shells. Now the manufacturer, Spin Master, is facing a class-action lawsuit from a California mom who alleges her child's egg was a dud. The lawsuit, filed by Jodie Hejduk of Bakersfield, Calif., on behalf of what the suit says could be millions of consumers, claims Spin Master ran "a bait-and-switch marketing scheme." Hatchimals are plush animals stuffed into plastic eggs that, when the egg is rubbed and cuddled for about half an hour, should begin to peck their way out. While Spin Master acknowledges some of the toys didn't work as intended, the company tells CNBC it "provided troubleshooting support and where required immediately made available replacement products." The toy cost about $50 in stores, but it was so popular it spawned internet bidding up to $350—only to leave many buyers disappointed. One customer wrote on Amazon.com that she "watched every YouTube video we could for help, but to no avail," the lawsuit says, per NBC News. Others complained that calling Spin Master had done no good because the company was "impossible to contact," or that when they got through they were told to open the egg themselves. Spin Master blames the toy's popularity, saying the company "experienced a higher than anticipated number of calls" over the holidays, and that the lawsuit's allegations are "not based on actual facts." But an attorney on the case tells Courthouse News that the toy's failure rate is "exceptionally high," and that the company knew the product wasn't ready for market. Hejduk's lawyer, Mark Geragos, tells ABC News his client was never offered a refund for her defective Hatchimal.

A discovery claimed by American explorer Barry Clifford as the wreck of Christopher Columbus's flagship, the Santa Maria, off the coast of Haiti has been disputed by Unesco. Unesco experts have concluded that the wreck is not from the 15th century, but from a later period, around the 17th or 18th century. The experts based their conclusion on the fasteners found at the site, which indicated a ship construction technique that dates the ship to the late 17th or 18th century.

The Santa Maria, the largest ship in Columbus's expedition, ran aground near Haiti in December 1492. Columbus and his crew had stripped timbers from the ship to build an outpost or fort, but the crew disappeared and the fort was burned down before Columbus returned the following year. The wreck of the Santa Maria was never found.

Barry Clifford had announced in May that he had found the wreck of Columbus's flagship, citing geographical, underwater topography, and archaeological evidence. He believed that a full excavation of the wreck would yield detailed marine archaeological evidence of Columbus's discovery of America. However, Unesco's rejection of Clifford's site has been met with criticism from some scholars, who argue that Unesco's report ignores photographic evidence for Columbus-era cannon on the site, evidence from an expedition that may have visited the site in 1960, and crucial evidence from the ballast and bronze objects found on the site.

Unesco now plans to look for the Santa Maria in different locations, both on land and on the seabed. The organization believes that the Santa Maria could be buried under sediment on what used to be the seabed and is now coastal marshland. However, many scholars argue that Columbus's vessel could not have reached the marshland due to shallow and dangerous reefs.

The Santa Maria was the flagship of Columbus's three-vessel fleet that discovered the Americas. The fleet first reached the Americas on 12 October 1492, and the Santa Maria ran aground on a reef and could not be refloated. The ship's seams opened, and it was flooded. Columbus
answers: The United Nations' cultural body is on the trail of Christopher Columbus' flagship—and it says the wreck that an expedition identified as the Santa Maria earlier this year is a different, much younger ship. As predicted by authorities in Haiti, UNESCO experts say there is "indisputable proof" that the wreck found off the country's north coast is from a much later period than 1492, reports the BBC. UNESCO says the wreck is further from shore than accounts of Columbus' first voyage, and bronze or copper fasteners found at the site are evidence of shipbuilding techniques that date the ship to the late 17th or 18th century at the earliest. UNESCO says it believes the wreck may lie "under coastal sediment" in what is now marshland and has called for further investigation of the area. Marine archaeologist Barry Clifford, who first investigated the wreck 11 years ago, says Columbus-era lombard cannons spotted in the area are crucial pieces of evidence that now appear to have been looted from the site, the Independent reports. "The lombards are the smoking guns and, in my view, the most important pieces of evidence in the search for the Santa Maria," he says. (Columbus wrote about the 1492 sinking of the Santa Maria in his journal, but one historian believes that the explorer lied about the ship's fate as part of a spy plot.)

answers: A judge in Florida has allowed a vegan mom who defied a doctor's orders to regain custody of her infant son, reports WFTV. The strange case began in June when police in Casselberry charged Sarah Markham with neglect and took away 2-week-old Caleb. The charges came after a pediatrician diagnosed Caleb as dehydrated and underweight, and told Markham to take him to the hospital immediately, recounts WKMG. Instead, Markham bought soy formula to supplement her breast milk. When she didn't show up at the hospital, police came to her house, and she told them she wanted a second doctor's opinion and stressed that she did not want her son getting formula from animal products. Today, a Seminole County judge granted her custody again with the provision that she provide a nutritionist's report in 10 days. "There's no case, there's no abuse, there's no neglect—there's simply a doctor who has been challenged by a mother, and he didn't like it," says Caleb's grandfather, Bo Markham. The child has been with his grandparents since he was taken out of his mother's care, and now weighs about 17 pounds. "He's still on a soy formula," says Bo Markham. The criminal neglect charges are still pending, though Sarah Markham's attorney—Mark O'Mara, who defended George Zimmerman—says he expects they will be dismissed now.
